content.text: On Fig. 1.1, mark suitable positions for the four pins. Label the pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) , \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
Draw the normal at point \(\mathbf{A}\)
Draw in the line \(\mathbf{AB}\). Measure and record the angle of refraction \(r\) between and the normal
r =
Measure and record the angle of incidence \(i\) between the incident ray and the normal
i =

The student does not have a set square or any other means to check that the pins are vertical. Suggest how he can ensure that his \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) positions are as accurate as possible
An IGCSE student is investigating the passage of light through a transparent block pins
The student's ray trace sheet is shown in Fig. 1.1

The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) to mark the incident ray. He looks through the block and places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) to mark the emergent ray so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear to be exactly one behind the other. He draws the outline of the block. He removes the block and pins and draws in the incident ray and the emergent ray
Fig. 1.1
The temperature of the hot water is shown in Fig. 2.1
Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\) of this hot water
Calculate the gain in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) of the cold water using the equation
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\)
\(E_{\mathrm{c}} =\)
Calculate the loss in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) of the hot water using the equation
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\)
\(E_{\mathrm{h}} =\)

The student pours \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water. He briefly stirs the mixture and then records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) of the mixture, \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}} = 49^\circ \text{C}\)
State whether the experimental results support this suggestion. Justify your statement reference to the results
statement
justification
Suggest a practical reason in this experiment why \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) might be different from \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\)
The student suggests that all the thermal energy lost by the hot water is gained Thus \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) should be equal
Another student is asked to suggest quantities that should be kept constant if this experiment is repeated in order to check the readings. Table 2.1 shows the suggestions
Place a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the second column of the table next to each correctly suggested quantity

table.html:
suggested quantities
avoid parallax (line of sight) errors when taking readings
number of stirs
room temperature
starting temperature of hot water
use a digital thermometer
use only two or three significant figures for the final answers

content.text: An IGCSE student is investigating the energy changes that occur when hot water are mixed
The student is provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of cold water
The temperature of the cold water \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}} = 23^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Complete the heading for each column of the table
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each length \(l\) of the wire using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Record the values of \(R\) in the table
A student measures and records in Table 3.1 the current \(I\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V\) across a length \(l = 0.250 \text{m}\) of wire \(\mathbf{PQ}\)
She repeats the procedure using \(l\) values of \(0.500 \text{m}\) and \(0.750 \text{m}\)
Use numbers from the table to suggest and justify a relationship between the wire and its resistance \(R\). Show your working
Use the results to predict the resistance of a \(1.50 \text{m}\) length of the same wire. Show your working
prediction .........
Another student proposes that the accuracy of the experiment would be improved by using a \(12\mathrm{V}\) power source
Suggest two effects that this might have on the experiment
The IGCSE class is investigating the resistance of a wire
The circuit is shown in Fig. 3.1
State and briefly explain one precaution you would take in order to obtain reliable measurements in this experiment
precaution
explanation
Plot the graph of \(\frac{1}{\nu} /\frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((y\text{-axis})\) against \(\frac{1}{u} /\frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((x\text{-axis})\). Both axes must start at 0 at to 7.0
Use the graph to find the intercept on the \(y\)-axis
intercept on the \(y\)-axis =
Use the graph to find the intercept on the \(x\)-axis
intercept on the \(x\)-axis =
The IGCSE class is investigating the formation of images by a lens
Fig 4.1 shows the apparatus

A student places the screen about \(1.0 \text{m}\) from the illuminated object. He places the lens between the object and the screen at a distance \(u = 0.200 \text{m}\) from the object. He adjusts the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. He records the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. He repeats the procedure using different values of \(u\). The readings are shown in Table 4.1
On Fig 5.1, measure the height \(h\), width \(w\) and depth \(d\) of the cube-shaped piece of modelling clay
Calculate the volume \(V\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(V = hwd.\)
V =
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m}{V}\), where the mass of the modelling clay \(m = 103 \text{g}\)
Method 1
A student moulds a piece of modelling clay into a cube shape as shown in Fig. 5.1
Record the volume of water \(V_{1}\) in the measuring cylinder, as shown in Fig. 5.2a
Record the new volume \(V_{2}\) in the measuring cylinder, as shown in Fig. 5.2b
Describe briefly one precaution you would take to read the measuring cylinder correctly
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{s}} = (V_{2} - V_{1})\)
Vs =
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m_{\mathrm{s}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}},\) where \(m_{\mathrm{s}} = 34.5 \text{g}\)
Method 2
The student cuts the piece of modelling clay into two pieces. One piece is approximately the size of the other piece. The mass \(m_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the smaller piece is \(34.5\mathrm{g}\)
Fig. 5.2a shows a measuring cylinder containing water. Fig. 5.2b shows the same measuring cylinder after the smaller piece of modelling clay has been lowered into it
Assuming that the experiment has been carried out with care, suggest two the two values obtained for the density of the modelling clay in (a) and (b) may same
State which of the two methods for determining density (method 1 or method 2) you judge to be less accurate. Give a reason for your judgement
method
reason
The IGSCCE class is determining the density of modelling clay by two methods
